examples.translation: I have a backache. / My back hurts.

examples.sentence: Necesito un masaje en la espalda.

collocations: dar la espalda (to turn one's back)

examples.translation: Sit down and lean against the back (of the chair).

examples.sentence: Esta silla tiene una espalda muy alta.
examples.translation: This chair has a very high back.

examples.sentence: Ya no quiero tener esa responsabilidad sobre mi espalda.
examples.translation: I don't want to have that responsibility on my back anymore.

collocations: tener algo sobre la espalda (to have something on one's back)

etymology.value: From Latin *spatula*, diminutive of *spatha* (“broad, flat object; blade”).

usage_notes.explanation: 'Espalda' refers to the back of a person or animal. It can also refer to the back of an object like a chair. Figuratively, it can mean a burden or responsibility. The expression 'dar la espalda' means to turn one's back on someone, either literally or figuratively (to abandon or ignore).

examples.note: In Spanish, it's more common to use 'me duele' (it hurts me) rather than 'tengo dolor en mi' (I have pain in my) when referring to body pain.

idioms_phrases: cubrirse las espaldas (to cover one's back)
echarse algo a la espalda (to take something upon oneself)
tener tablas en la espalda (to be very experienced)

readability_explanation.text: 'Espalda' means 'back' in English. It refers to the part of your body that is behind you, from your shoulders to your waist. You can use it to talk about back pain or needing a massage. It can also refer to the back of a chair.

example_sentences.sentence: El nadador tiene músculos fuertes en la espalda.
example_sentences.translation: The swimmer has strong back muscles.

example_sentences.sentence: La silla de oficina tiene un buen soporte para la espalda.
example_sentences.translation: The office chair has good back support.

example_sentences.sentence: Siento el peso del mundo sobre mi espalda.
example_sentences.translation: I feel the weight of the world on my shoulders.
